ETYMOLOGY: From Latin praetextum (neuter past participle of praetexere 'to weave in front', 'to outwardly display', 'to use as a pretext'), from prae- 'before' + texere 'to weave'. Originally referred to the outer border of a toga, then by extension, to something used as a cover or an excuse.

MEANINGS.PATTERN: a pretext (for doing sth) | a pretext (to do sth) | under the pretext of sth/doing sth
MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A noun is a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, things, qualities, or actions.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A reason given in justification of a course of action that is not the real reason; an excuse.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 借口；托词；用来掩饰真实意图的理由。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: He left the party early on the pretext of having a headache.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他以头痛为借口提前离开了派对。
